status.description: The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.
status.name: Open

worklogs.comment:
blink1073 commented on PR #13826:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/13826#issuecomment-1209572029

   I tried to come up with a suitable test for this, but we only run into the issue in PyMongoArrow because we are explicitly including binary files by path instead of relying on `ext.library_dirs` as is done in `test_cython.py`.

github-actions[bot] commented on PR #13826:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/13826#issuecomment-1209616247

   :warning: Ticket **has not been started in JIRA**, please click 'Start Progress'.

pitrou commented on PR #13826:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/13826#issuecomment-1227143445

   I'm a bit surprised. How are you using PyArrow exactly? Are you trying to link to Parquet C++ APIs?

pitrou commented on PR #13826:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/13826#issuecomment-1227149544

   Oh, I see: `libarrow_python` links to `libparquet` for Parquet encryption support.

pitrou commented on PR #13826:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/13826#issuecomment-1227150419

   That said, I wonder why the transitive dependency isn't picked up automatically.

blink1073 commented on PR #13826:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/13826#issuecomment-1227356110

   We are vendoring the specific arrow binary files by path, copying them into our build directory.  We do this because we use them at runtime for the array builders.   
   
   We use the list given by `get_libraries()` to select which files to vendor specifically using `module.extra_link_args.append(path)` instead of ` module.libraries.append('arrow')`.  
   
   Our logic is [here](https://github.com/mongodb-labs/mongo-arrow/blob/d1bb5ebeffd61ec53a8acf4c4c8484ef078471a2/bindings/python/setup.py#L128).

pitrou commented on PR #13826:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/13826#issuecomment-1227386632

   Hmm, I'm not sure that's the intended use for `get_libraries`. Basically, `get_libraries` allows you to [link your C++ or Cython code](https://arrow.apache.org/docs/python/integration/extending.html#example) to the Arrow Python libraries, but it doesn't list transitive dependencies. It also doesn't capture additional Arrow libraries such as `libarrow_flight`, `libgandiva`...
   
   @jorisvandenbossche @xhochy What do you think?

blink1073 commented on PR #13826:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/13826#issuecomment-1227390507

   We are linking Cython code FWIW.  I can try to refactor to use `module.libraries` instead of `module.extra_link_args`.

pitrou commented on PR #13826:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/13826#issuecomment-1227392293

   Yes, but the part where `get_libraries()` isn't enough is because you are also copying the DLL files instead of simply distributing the entire PyArrow package, right?

blink1073 commented on PR #13826:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/13826#issuecomment-1227404519

   Yes, we're using `get_libraries()` as a proxy for the names of files to copy over, optionally with the version string in the file name.

blink1073 commented on PR #13826:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/13826#issuecomment-1227759384

   I tried using the approach from the [Cython example](https://arrow.apache.org/docs/python/integration/extending.html#example), but it is failing during [auditwheel](https://github.com/blink1073/mongo-arrow/runs/8025066266?check_suite_focus=true): "ValueError: Cannot repair wheel, because required library "libarrow_python.so.900" could not be located".

blink1073 commented on PR #13826:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/13826#issuecomment-1229054817

   Okay, I was able to use the recommended approach along with wheel repair, with one interesting [snag](https://github.com/blink1073/mongo-arrow/runs/8044467641?check_suite_focus=true).  Because I am setting `DYLD_LIBRARY_PATH` before calling `delocate` on macos, the `pyarrow._json` module overshadows the optional one in the stdlib:
   
   ```python
   File "/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.10/lib/python3.10/json/scanner.py", line 5, in <module>
         from _json import make_scanner as c_make_scanner
       File "pyarrow/_json.pyx", line 1, in init pyarrow._json
       File "/private/var/folders/24/8k48jl6d249_n_qfxwsl6xvm0000gn/T/cibw-run-d7ri7rrm/cp310-macosx_x86_64/build/venv/lib/python3.10/site-packages/pyarrow/__init__.py", line 65, in <module>
   ```
   
   I was able to work around it my making sure that the appropriate `lib-dynload` folder was ahead of the `pyarrow` folder on `DYLD_LIBRARY_PATH`, but perhaps the module should be renamed in `pyarrow`?  I think we should close this pull request in favor of one that renames `pyarrow._json`.

blink1073 commented on PR #13826:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/13826#issuecomment-1230711676

   I'd also be happy to create an integration test where we build a wheel and repair it across the three platforms as part of that new issue.

issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

fields.description:
We are updating {{PyMongoArrow}} to use PyArrow 8.0, and saw the following [failure| https://github.com/mongodb-labs/mongo-arrow/runs/7696619223?check_suite_focus=true] when building wheels:  "@rpath/libparquet.800.dylib not found".

We overcame the error by explicitly adding "parquet" to the list of libraries returned by {{get_libraries}}.  I am happy to submit a PR.
fields.summary: [Python] Parquet should be listed in PyArrow's get_libraries() function

comments.body:
Yes, please do submit a PR!

I can reproduce locally as well. Surprising we don't have any tests for that function.

Out of curiosity, do you have an idea why this started to fail with pyarrow 8.0? (I am not aware of something we have changed regarding this, and pyarrow has been built against a parquet library for a long time)

Ah, actually, pyarrow itself has always been built against libparquet (and included this in the wheels), but for the arrow_python library itself this dependency was indeed introduced in 8.0 with ARROW-9947.

Anything else I need to do?  In order to add a proper regression test we'd need a new test in {{test_cython}} that copied specific library files into a wheel, and then attempted to repair the wheel.   This would add a test dependency on {{delocate}} on macOS and {{auditwheel}} on linux.

[~willjones127] {{get_libraries()}} is tested in {{test_cython.py}}.

I wonder what is different here that requires adding {{parquet}} while the tests generally run fine.
